                  State v. Marsh & McLennan Cos.
                  Supreme Court of Connecticut
                  January 4, 2008, Argued; April 15, 2008, Officially Released
                  SC 17861
                  Reporter
                  286 Conn. 454 *; 944 A.2d 315 **; 2008 Conn. LEXIS 128 ***; 2008-1 Trade Cas. (CCH) P76,173
                  STATE OF CONNECTICUT v. MARSH AND MCLENNAN COMPANIES, INC., ET AL.
                  Prior History:  [***1] Action by the state as parens patriae to recover damages for, inter alia, violations of the state
                  antitrust statutes and for certain unfair and deceptive acts and practices by the named defendant in allegedly
                  conspiring to increase premium prices in the excess casualty insurance market, and for other relief, brought to the
                  Superior Court in the judicial district of Stamford, Complex Litigation Docket, where the court, Shay, J., granted the
                  defendants' motion to strike with respect to the state's claim for general economic damages and, sua sponte,
                  dismissed for lack of jurisdiction the state's statutory claim for those damages, from which the state, upon
                  certification by the acting Chief Justice pursuant to General Statutes § 52-265a that a matter of substantial public
                  interest is at issue, appealed to this court.
                  State v. Marsh & McLennan Cos., 2007 Conn. Super. LEXIS 216 (Conn. Super. Ct., Jan. 25, 2007)
                  Disposition: Reversed; further proceedings.

                  HN2[
                  ]  Standards of Review, De Novo Review
                  A motion to dismiss tests, inter alia, whether, on the face of the record, a court is without jurisdiction. A review of the
                  court's ultimate legal conclusion and resulting determination of the motion to dismiss will be de novo. When a court
                  decides a jurisdictional question raised by a pretrial motion to dismiss, it must consider the allegations of the
                  complaint in their most favorable light. In that regard, a court must take the facts to be those alleged in the
                  complaint, including those facts necessarily implied from the allegations, construing them in a manner most
                  favorable to the pleader. The motion to dismiss admits all facts which are well pleaded, invokes the existing record,
                  and must be decided upon that alone.
                  Civil Procedure > Appeals > Standards of Review > General Overview
                  Governments > Legislation > Interpretation
                  Civil Procedure > Appeals > Standards of Review > Questions of Fact & Law
                  HN3[
                  ]  Appeals, Standards of Review
                  A question of statutory construction is a question of law over which a reviewing court exercises plenary review. The
                  process of statutory interpretation involves the determination of the meaning of the statutory language as applied to
                  the facts of a case, including the question of whether the language does so apply.
                  Civil Procedure > Appeals > Standards of Review > General Overview
                  Governments > Legislation > Interpretation
                  HN4[
                  ]  Appeals, Standards of Review
                  When construing a statute, a reviewing court's fundamental objective is to ascertain and give effect to the apparent
                  intent of the legislature. In other words, reviewing courts seek to determine, in a reasoned manner, the meaning of
                  the statutory language as applied to the facts of a case, including the question of whether the language actually
                  does apply. In seeking to determine that meaning, Conn. Gen. Stat. § 1-2z directs a reviewing court first to consider
                  the text of the statute itself and its relationship to other statutes. If, after examining such text and considering such
                  relationship, the meaning of such text is plain and unambiguous and does not yield absurd or unworkable results,
                  extratextual evidence of the meaning of the statute shall not be considered. The test to determine ambiguity is
                  whether the statute, when read in context, is susceptible to more than one reasonable interpretation.
                  Antitrust & Trade Law > Public Enforcement > State Civil Actions
                  HN5[
                  ]  Public Enforcement, State Civil Actions
                  The language of Conn. Gen. Stat. § 35-32(c)(2) permits the attorney general to bring an action in the name of the
                  state as parens patriae with respect to damages to the general economy of the state or any political subdivision
                  thereof provided that such damages shall not be duplicative of those recoverable under Conn. Gen. Stat. § 35-
                  32(c)(1). Conn. Gen. Stat. § 35-32(c)(1) permits the attorney general to bring an action as parens patriae for
                  286 Conn. 454, *454; 944 A.2d 315, **315; 2008 Conn. LEXIS 128, ***1
                  
                  
                  persons residing in the state with respect to damages sustained by such persons, or, if the court finds in its
                  discretion that the interests of justice so require, as a representative of a class or classes consisting of persons
                  residing in the state who have been damaged.

                  See 15 U.S.C.S. § 15c.
                  Antitrust & Trade Law > General Overview
                  Civil Procedure > ... > Justiciability > Standing > General Overview
                  Antitrust & Trade Law > Public Enforcement > State Civil Actions
                  Civil Procedure > Appeals > Standards of Review > General Overview
                  HN8[
                  ]  Antitrust & Trade Law
                  Conn. Gen. Stat. § 35-44b does not deprive the state of standing to pursue a parens patriae action for antitrust
                  damages to its general economy pursuant to Conn. Gen. Stat. § 35-32(c)(2) or, put differently, require a reviewing
                  court to incorporate the federal preclusion of general economy damages into the state antitrust scheme.
                  Antitrust & Trade Law > General Overview
                  Civil Procedure > ... > Justiciability > Standing > General Overview

                  HN9[
                  ]  Antitrust & Trade Law
                  Conn. Gen. Stat. § 35-32(c)(2) confers standing upon the state to pursue a parens patriae claim for antitrust
                  damages to its general economy.
                  Civil Procedure > ... > Defenses, Demurrers & Objections > Motions to Dismiss > Failure to State Claim
                  Civil Procedure > ... > Defenses, Demurrers & Objections > Motions to Strike > General Overview
                  286 Conn. 454, *454; 944 A.2d 315, **315; 2008 Conn. LEXIS 128, ***1
                  
                  
                  Civil Procedure > ... > Pleadings > Complaints > General Overview
                  Civil Procedure > Appeals > Standards of Review > General Overview
                  HN10[
                  ]  Motions to Dismiss, Failure to State Claim
                  Like a motion to dismiss, a motion to strike challenges the legal sufficiency of a pleading and, consequently,
                  requires no factual findings by a trial court. As a result, a reviewing court's review of the trial court's ruling is plenary.
                  Reviewing courts take the facts to be those alleged in the complaint that has been stricken and construe the
                  complaint in the manner most favorable to sustaining its legal sufficiency. If facts provable in the complaint would
                  support a cause of action, the motion to strike must be denied. Thus, reviewing courts assume the truth of both the
                  specific factual allegations and any facts fairly provable thereunder. In doing so, moreover, reviewing courts read
                  the allegations broadly rather than narrowly.
